para: The Forward Euler method is the simplest method of numerically integrating ordinary differential equations. The individual steps are very quick to compute, but the method is often unstable, requiring very small step sizes. It is first order in time, meaning that it makes an error of order \( (\Delta t)^2 \) on each step.

Given a vector \(\phi_n\) of unknowns (i.e. &field; values in &oof2;) at time \(t_n\), and the first order differential equation
\[ \frac{d\phi}{dt} = f(\phi, t) \]
the Forward Euler estimate for \(\phi_{n+1}\) is
\[ \phi_{n+1} = \phi_n + \Delta t f(\phi_n, t_n) \]
where \( \Delta t = t_{n+1}-t_n \).

ForwardEuler can be applied to equations with second order time derivatives
\[ \frac{d^2\phi}{dt^2} = g(\phi, t) \]
by defining new variables
\[ \psi = \frac{d\phi}{dt} \]
and solving the augmented set of first order equations
\begin{align*} \frac{d\psi}{dt} &= g(\phi, t) \\ \frac{d\phi}{dt} &= \psi \end{align*}
ForwardEuler works equally well for linear and nonlinear equations. Because the method is explicit, equation doesn't require a nonlinear solver even if \(f\) is nonlinear.
